unnormalised: Hey there, nature lovers! Good news coming out of the Jim Corbett National Park. Dr. Anjali Sharma and her team at the Wildlife Institute of India (WII) have reported a significant increase in tiger sightings, a whopping 15% jump this year!
normalised: Hey there, nature lovers! Good news coming out of the Jim Corbett National Park. Doctor Anjali Sharma and her team at the Wildlife Institute of India (W I I) have reported a significant increase in tiger sightings, a whopping fifteen percent jump this year!

unnormalised: This is largely attributed to community-led conservation efforts in villages like Dhikala and Ramnagar. Villagers are actively participating in anti-poaching patrols and habitat restoration.
normalised: This is largely attributed to community-led conservation efforts in villages like Dhikala and Ramnagar. Villagers are actively participating in anti-poaching patrols and habitat restoration.

unnormalised: The Forest Department has also been instrumental, planting native trees and clearing invasive species, expanding suitable habitat by an estimated 5000 sq ft.
normalised: The Forest Department has also been instrumental, planting native trees and clearing invasive species, expanding suitable habitat by an estimated five thousand square feet.

unnormalised: Rs. 2 Crores have been allocated by the MoEFCC (Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change) for further initiatives, including upgrading anti-poaching camps and providing better equipment for forest guards.
normalised: Rupees two crores have been allocated by the M O E F C C (Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change) for further initiatives, including upgrading anti-poaching camps and providing better equipment for forest guards.

unnormalised: This collaborative approach seems to be working wonders, ensuring that the roar of the Royal Bengal Tiger continues to echo through our forests. A big shoutout to everyone involved in protecting our majestic wildlife! Let's hope this trend continues and we see even more good news from conservation fronts across India. Keep those binoculars handy!
normalised: This collaborative approach seems to be working wonders, ensuring that the roar of the Royal Bengal Tiger continues to echo through our forests. A big shoutout to everyone involved in protecting our majestic wildlife! Let's hope this trend continues and we see even more good news from conservation fronts across India. Keep those binoculars handy!
